supporting.text: Contract law in most jurisdictions explicitly requires mutual assent (offer and acceptance) for a contract to be valid.

attacks.text: Contract law in most jurisdictions explicitly requires mutual assent (offer and acceptance) for a contract to be valid.
Some jurisdictions recognize unilateral contracts, where only one party makes a promise in exchange for an act by another, without explicit mutual assent.
Unilateral contracts still imply a form of mutual agreement, as the performing party's act constitutes acceptance of the offer, maintaining the principle of mutual assent.
Implied contracts can be enforced without explicit mutual agreement, as courts infer assent from the parties' conduct or circumstances.
Implied contracts still rely on the parties' behavior indicating mutual intent to be bound, preserving the underlying requirement of mutual assent.
